repnme.cdata!: India - Shrimp and Fish Culture Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, though, institutional
            development impacts are only modest. Key lessons address the
            need for: 1) government agencies to avoid direct involvement
            in commercial operations, rather, involve itself only in
            regulatory aspects, provision of technical back-stopping,
            and resolution of technical problems with wide implications
            for the industry. Commercialization should be left to the
            private sector, including assistance to beneficiaries
            regarding procurement, management, marketing, and
            operations; 2) complex project design, and back-up support
            to reflect beneficiaries' abilities, i.e., the scope of
            operation, engineering, and organizational requirements must
            be within targeted beneficiaries; likewise, the intensity of
            involvement of site management, must reflect the
            beneficiaries' capabilities; 3) appropriate policies,
            and regulations to guide aquaculture development, backed by
            effective institutions, capable of addressing social,
            technical, and environmental problems, such as displacing
            existing fishermen, or users of the resource, disease
            problems, or effluent disposal; 4) realistic sequencing of
            project developments, outlining that in the absence of a
            completed technical, and organizational design by the
            proposed start-up date, the first two years of
            implementation, should be dedicated to preparing target
            beneficiaries, through pilot trials, and, completing all
            engineering, and organizational plans; and, 5) institutional
            capacity, backed by qualified, skilled staff to ensure
            resolution of problems, and timely implementation.
            Similarly, technical qualifications of Bank teams should
            ensure comprehensive planning, and supervisory standards.

18152467.theme: Other environment and natural resources management,Rural non-farm income generation,Infrastructure services for private sector development
18152467.trustfund:
TF026530-TAGPE - ENVIR. TECHNICAL
            ASSISTANCE FUND,TF027620-FISHERIES DEVELOPMENT
18152467.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!: India - Shrimp and Fish Culture Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project helps India maintain its
            position as a major world exporter of shrimps, for which it
            has a comparative advantage because of its low labor costs
            and conducive climate. This project, implemented over a
            seven year period, comprises: (a) a brackish water shrimp
            component located in the states of West Bengal, Orissa, and
            Andhra Pradesh, which would represent about 80% of the
            project cost; (b) an inland fisheries component located in
            West Bengal, Orissa, Andhra Pradesh, Bihar and Uttar
            Pradesh, which would represent about 8% of the project cost;
            and (c) project management including environmental
            management and training representing about 12% of project
            cost. The shrimp component would be the more complex as it
            would support the first real thrust to introduce the
            technologically advanced semi-intensive shrimp culture
            (compared to the traditional extensive culture) to India in
            a large way. It would involve a development cost of almost
            Rs 300,000 (US $11,000) per ha, and would require the close
            coordination between shrimp production, hatcheries and feed.
            However, its benefits would be significant both in terms of
            foreign exchange earnings and income to the beneficiaries.
            The inland fisheries component would require very little
            infrastructural cost, and the provision of support equipment
            and services. The technology is simple and is already well
            known. Through increased stocking and the institutional
            reform provided, this component is expected to benefit the poor.
